name: 文學作品導讀（一）
description: The goal of this course is to provide students with a reasonably compact introduction to the study and appreciation of fiction, poetry, and drama. The selected literary works are studied in terms of basic elements such as plot, setting, point of view, theme, style and tone, symbolism and also in terms of critical concepts and approaches so as to enhance students’ meaningful reading of literature and to heighten their sensibility and appreciation of aesthetic, social, cultural, ethical, and philosophical dimensions of literary expressions.
goals: Learn key terms and concepts generally applied to the evaluation of literature
Hone skills of close reading and critical thinking
Develop curiosity about the world through context-specific analysis of literary works
Improve sensitivity to the English language

**Course Description**

This course provides students with an introduction to the study and appreciation of fiction, poetry, and drama (fiction will be covered in the fall semester, poetry and drama in the spring). We will consider the basic elements of literature, such as plot and setting, as well as the broader figurative meanings of literature. Students will also learn how to write academic responses to literature.  
  

**Attendance, Participation, and Group Assignments**

Students are expected to regularly attend and contribute to class discussions. Group assignments will consist of written responses that you will complete with other students in class. We will have six group response assignments this semester (they are marked **GA** on the schedule below).

**Midterm and Final Exams**

The midterm and final exams will be a combination of some short and one long written responses.  The short responses will be related to “basic elements” of literature (plot, setting, etc.). The long response will be just like the ones you do in the group assignments, but you will be asked to write on a passage from one of the stories that you did _not_ write about in groups.

**Schedule**

Week 1, 9/14: Introduction and Syllabus Review; David Foster Wallace, “Everything is Green”

Week 2, 9/21: Elements of Fiction: “Plot” (82-89); Nathaniel Hawthorne, “The Birth-Mark” (290-302)

Week 3, 9/28: Flannery O’Connor, “A Good Man is Hard to Find” (422-433); How to Write a Response to Literature

Week 4, 10/5: Kate Chopin, “The Story of an Hour” (475-477); **GA**

Week 5, 10/12: John Updike, “A & P” (148-153); **GA**  

Week 6, 10/19: Elements of Fiction: “Narration and Point of View” (160-164); A. S. Byatt, “The Thing in the Forest” (302-317)

Week 7, 10/26: James Joyce, “Araby” (153-159); **GA**

Week 8, 11/2: Elements of Fiction: “Character” (180-187); Karen Russell, “St. Lucy’s Home for Girls Raised by Wolves” (229-241)

Week 9, 11/9: Midterm Exam

Week 10, 11/16: Elements of Fiction: “Setting” (245-251); Charlotte Perkins Gilman, “The Yellow Wallpaper” (478-489)

Week 11, 11/23: Ambrose Bierce, “An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge” (551-557); **GA**

Week 12, 11/30: Elements of Fiction: “Symbol and Figurative Language” (285-290); Franz Kafka, “The Hunger Artist” (594-600)

Week 13, 12/7: George Saunders, “Puppy” (172-178); **GA**

Week 14, 12/14: Elements of Fiction: “Theme” (334-338); D. H. Lawrence, “The Rocking-Horse Winner” (601-612)

Week 15, 12/21: John Cheever, “The Country Husband” (565-583)

Week 16, 12/28: William Faulkner, “A Rose for Emily” (516-522); **GA**

Week 17, 1/4: Herman Melville, “Bartleby, The Scrivener” (622-648)

Week 18, 1/11: Final Exam
